content: The Act is titled the "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act". It includes a requirement for cost-benefit analysis for certain prudential regulations. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates that Federal banking agencies must justify any prudential regulation stricter than international standards with a cost-benefit analysis. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" requires Federal banking agencies to justify stricter prudential regulations compared to international standards with a cost-benefit analysis, considering impacts on credit availability, liquidity, competitiveness of institutions, and economic factors. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates Federal banking agencies to assess the impact of stricter prudential regulations on credit availability, liquidity, competitiveness of institutions, employment, economic growth, and monetary policy execution. Additionally, agencies must seek public input before implementing regulations that would supersede existing ones. The Federal banking agencies must propose to repeal or amend superseded prudential regulations, or provide a rationale for not doing so, after implementing international standards. This includes a comprehensive analysis of the costs and benefits of the regulation post-adoption. The appropriate Federal banking agencies must report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of this Act on any prudential regulations that are more stringent than international standards or have been superseded. The report should include a description and analysis of the rule in question. (d) Definitions.--For purposes of this section, "appropriate Federal banking agency" refers to the agency defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, "banking organization" includes depository institutions and holding companies, and "corresponding international prudential standard" is also defined. The term "organization" refers to a depository institution or a depository institution holding company as defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The term "corresponding international prudential standard" refers to an international standard that a prudential regulation is based on, derived from, or similar to. "Prudential regulation" refers to any rule or regulation related to capital. Prudential regulation pertains to rules regarding capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. It includes setting minimum requirements for capital, debt, and liquid assets in relation to assets, exposures, or cash flows. Prudential regulation pertains to setting minimum requirements for capital, debt, and liquid assets in relation to assets, exposures, or cash flows, without imposing any specific ratios or conditions on banking organizations. Prudential regulation implements international standards based on global prudential standards adopted by international institutions like the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision. The curr_chunk discusses international standards adopted by institutions like the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision regarding capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. The curr_chunk defines superseded prudential regulation as regulations that set minimum requirements on a banking organization's capital, debt, or liquid assets. The term "superseded prudential regulation" refers to regulations that address similar risks or achieve similar goals as an international standard.
